questions.text: Angle subtended by 6/6 letter in Snellen chart from 6 m?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The Snellen chart is designed so that the 6/6 line is seen at an angle of 5 minutes of arc (5') from a distance of 6 meters (20 feet) Each individual stroke of the letter subtends 1 minute of arc (1') This means the whole letter subtends 5 minutes of arc Incorrect Options: B) 10 – This would be too large for normal vision acuity C) 15 – Larger than the standard 6/6 letter size D) 20 – Seen in low visual acuity conditions, not in normal vision

questions.text: Optic nerve head changes in glaucoma are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Roenne nasal step is a visual field defect, not an optic nerve head change. It occurs due to selective damage to arcuate nerve fibers, leading to nasal step defect on perimetry. Optic nerve head changes are structural, while Roenne nasal step is a functional change detected in visual field testing Optic nerve head (ONH) changes in glaucoma typically involve progressive cupping and neuroretinal rim thinning. The characteristic ONH changes include Option A: Cup-disc ratio change – Increased C/D ratio due to progressive loss of retinal ganglion cells Option B: Bayonetting – Bending/kinking of blood vessels as they pass over the deepened cup Option D: Nasal shifting of vessels – As the cup enlarges, blood vessels shift nasally

questions.text: Which of these is seen in optic neuritis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Optic neuritis is an inflammatory demyelinating disorder affecting the optic nerve, often associated with multiple sclerosis (MS) Marcus Gunn Pupil (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect - RAPD) • Seen in unilateral or asymmetric optic nerve damage • Swinging flashlight test reveals a paradoxical dilation of the affected pupil Incorrect Options: B) Seen in multiple myeloma: Optic neuritis is NOT associated with multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma can cause hyperviscosity syndrome and retinopathy, but not optic neuritis C) Oral steroids are given initially: Oral steroids are NOT the first-line treatment. High-dose IV methylprednisolone is preferred as initial treatment, followed by oral steroids in some cases. Oral steroids alone increase the risk of recurrence D) CECT is done for diagnosis: MRI with contrast is the imaging of choice to evaluate the optic nerve and look for white matter lesions in multiple sclerosis

questions.text: What is not seen in keratoconus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Haab Striae is not seen in keratoconus. These are horizontal breaks in Descemet’s membrane seen in congenital glaucoma, not in keratoconus keratoconus is a progressive thinning and conical protrusion of the cornea, leading to irregular astigmatism and visual distortion Option A) Munson Sign: Protrusion of the lower eyelid when the patient looks downward due to corneal coning Option B) Scissoring Reflex: Observed on retinoscopy, showing distorted light reflex due to corneal irregularity Option D) Irregular Astigmatism due to uneven corneal thinning and protrusion, leading to distorted vision uncorrectable by glasses

questions.text: A pregnant lady presents with retro-orbital pain, pulsatile proptosis, diplopia, tinnitus of one eye. IOP, BP and fundus were normal. Which structure are involved? A. Cavernous sinus B. ICA C. 6th nerve D. 3rd nerve
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The optic nerve (CN II) lies outside the cavernous sinus and is not directly involved in a CCF. IOP and fundus being normal further support that optic nerve function remains intact (no optic disc swelling or visual field loss) The patient presents with retro-orbital pain, pulsatile proptosis, diplopia, and tinnitus in one eye, which are classic features of a carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF). This condition involves abnormal communication between the internal carotid artery (ICA) and the cavernous sinus, leading to arterialization of venous structures. Involvement of Structures: Cavernous Sinus (A) The cavernous sinus is directly involved in a CCF, as it receives high-flow arterial blood from the ICA Internal Carotid Artery (B) The ICA forms an abnormal fistula with the cavernous sinus, causing pulsatile proptosis and increased venous pressure 6th Cranial Nerve (C) The abducent nerve (CN VI) runs within the cavernous sinus and is the most commonly affected nerve, leading to lateral rectus palsy (diplopia with esotropia)

questions.text: A fisherman with history of trauma with fishtail presents with symptoms of pain, blurring vision. What sign is there in pic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The fisherman has a history of trauma with a fishtail and presents with pain and blurring of vision, which raises suspicion for infectious or inflammatory involvement of the anterior chamber Hypopyon is pus collection in the anterior chamber, appearing as a layer of white-yellow exudate at the bottom of the anterior chamber due to leukocytes accumulation. Trauma with organic matter (like a fishtail) increases the risk of fungal corneal ulcer, which can present with pain, decreased vision, and hypopyon Hyphema (B): Blood in the anterior chamber, usually from blunt trauma or vessel rupture. It would appear reddish instead of white/yellow Aqueous Flares (C): Tyndall effect due to increased protein in aqueous humor, seen in uveitis. It would cause a hazy appearance but not a white fluid level Keratic Precipitates (D): Inflammatory deposits on the corneal endothelium in uveitis. It appears as fine or mutton-fat granules on slit-lamp examination, not a layered hypopyon

questions.text: Topical atropine in not used in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acute congestive glaucoma (also known as acute angle-closure glaucoma) occurs due to sudden closure of the trabecular meshwork by the iris, leading to a rapid rise in intraocular pressure (IOP). Atropine causes mydriasis, which further narrows the already closed angle, worsening the obstruction and increasing IOP dangerously. Instead, miotic agents like Pilocarpine are used to open the angle Incorrect Options: Malignant Glaucoma (B) also known as aqueous misdirection syndrome, it is a rare condition where the aqueous humor gets misdirected behind the iris, causing a shallow anterior chamber and high IOP. Atropine is actually used in malignant glaucoma to deepen the anterior chamber and relieve pupillary block Acute Anterior Uveitis (C): In uveitis, atropine is used to relieve pain, prevent posterior synechiae (adhesions between the iris and lens), and stabilize the blood-aqueous barrier. It helps in cycloplegia, reducing ciliary spasm and pain Corneal Ulcer (D): Atropine is used to prevent ciliary muscle spasm, reducing pain and secondary iritis. It does not delay healing significantly and is often given to relieve discomfort

questions.text: Most Common Cause of moderate to sever visual impairment according to 2015-20219 survey in india ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) According to the National Blindness & Visual Impairment Survey of India (2015-19): . The most common cause of moderate to severe visual impairment (MSVI) was: - Uncorrected refractive errors . These include: - Myopia - Hypermetropia - Astigmatism . Most are easily correctable with glasses or contact lenses, yet remain a major public health issue due to lack of access or awareness. Incorrect Options: B. Glaucoma Glaucoma is a major cause of irreversible C. Untreated Cataract Cataract is the leading cause of blindness, but not the leading cause of moderate to severe visual impairment. D. Diabetic Retinopathy An important and rising cause of visual impairment, but still less common than refractive errors for MSVI in the Indian context.

questions.text: Most common cause of blindness in India?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) According to a nationally representative survey conducted between 2015 and 2019 in India, the most common cause of moderate to severe visual impairment was untreated cataract Untreated Cataract: Accounted for 66.8% of moderate visual impairment cases and 83.9% of severe visual impairment cases Uncorrected Refractive Errors: Were the leading cause of mild visual impairment, responsible for 66.5% of such cases While uncorrected refractive errors are a significant cause of mild visual impairment, untreated cataracts remain the predominant cause of moderate to severe visual impairment in India

questions.text: Which nerve is not involved in oculocephalic reflex?)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The oculocephalic reflex (Doll's eye reflex) tests the integrity of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) and involves cranial nerves III (oculomotor), VI (abducens), and VIII (vestibulocochlear) CN VIII detects head movement and sends signals to the brainstem CN III, and VI coordinate extraocular muscle movements to maintain eye fixation Since CN IV (trochlear nerve) primarily controls the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for intorsion and depression of the eye in adduction, its role in the oculocephalic reflex is minimal

questions.text: Not related with complicated cataract
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (A) Krukenberg spindles ? These are pigment deposits on the corneal endothelium, typically seen in pigmentary glaucoma, not in complicated cataract (B) Occurs after uveitis ? Chronic uveitis can lead to complicated cataracts (C) Polychromatic lustre ? A shimmering, multicolored appearance seen in early complicated cataracts (D) Breadcrumb appearance ? A characteristic feature of posterior subcapsular cataracts, often seen in complicated cataracts

questions.text: A patient with icterus in eye with elevated liver enzymes, ataxia and rigidity
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Wilson's disease Eye - KF rings [Copper deposition in Descement membrane], Sunflower cataract KF ring reverses after treatment of Wilson's. Good prognostic sign KF rings also seen in - 1. Chalcosis [intraocular copper] 2. Biliary Cirrhosis

questions.text: What's most common ocular manifestation in COVID 19?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (A) Follicular conjunctivitis: Most common ocular finding in COVID-19. Presents with redness, tearing, foreign body sensation, and mild discharge, resembling viral conjunctivitis Other options: (B) Papillary conjunctivitis: More commonly associated with allergic conjunctivitis or bacterial infections, not COVID-19 (C) Mucormycosis: A severe fungal infection seen in post-COVID patients, especially those with diabetes and steroid use, but not the most common ocular manifestation (D) Uveitis: Rare in COVID-19; more often associated with autoimmune conditions or infections like TB, syphilis, or CMV

choices.text: It is of 2 types progressive and regressive
Simple excision will reduce recurrence by 95%
Consists of head neck and body

questions.text: Incorrect about the condition shown is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Simple excision alone has a high recurrence rate (30-50%). Recurrence is significantly reduced when combined with adjuvant therapies like conjunctival autograft or mitomycin C Other options: (A) It is of 2 types: progressive and regressive: Pterygium can be progressive (growing towards the visual axis) or regressive (remaining stable or shrinking) (B) Elastoid degeneration: Histologically, pterygium shows elastoid degeneration of the subconjunctival tissue (D) Consists of head, neck, body: Pterygium is anatomically divided into head, neck, and body

questions.text: Identify
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ankyloblepharon: Partial or complete fusion of the eyelid margins, preventing normal eyelid opening. It can be congenital or acquired due to trauma or inflammation Other options: Symblepharon: Adhesion between bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva, often seen in cicatricial conjunctivitis (e.g., Stevens-Johnson Syndrome, chemical burns) Trichiasis: Misdirected eyelashes that grow toward the cornea, causing irritation and corneal damage Entropion: Inward turning of the eyelid, leading to rubbing of eyelashes against the cornea

questions.text: Drug which increases trabecular outflow
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Netarsudil: A Rho kinase inhibitor that increases trabecular outflow by relaxing the trabecular meshwork Other options: Acetazolamide: A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces aqueous humor production but does not increase trabecular outflow Timolol: A beta-blocker that decreases aqueous humor production, but it does not significantly affect trabecular outflow Brimonidine: An alpha-2 agonist that reduces aqueous humor production and increases uveoscleral outflow, but its effect on trabecular outflow is minimal

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1 COLOUR VISION- ISHIHARA PERIPHERAL VISION- PERIMETRY [SUBJECTIVE TEST] INTRAOCULAR PRESSURE- GOLDMAN APPLANATION TONOMETRY [GOLD STANDARD] - IMBERT FICK LAW CENTRAL VISION- SLIT LAMP BIOMICROSCOPY

questions.text: The actions of superior oblique muscle are?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Actions of superior oblique muscle: • Primary action: Intorsion (inward rotation of the eyeball) • Secondary action: Depression (moves the eye downward) • Tertiary action: Abduction (moves the eye outward, away from the nose) Other options: A) Intorsion, Elevation, and Abduction: Incorrect because superior oblique depresses, not elevates B) Extorsion, Depression, Adduction: Incorrect because superior oblique causes intorsion, not extorsion, and it abducts, not adducts D) Intorsion, Elevation, and Adduction: Incorrect because superior oblique depresses, not elevates, and it abducts, not adducts

questions.text: Which of the following triad is seen associated with angle closure glaucoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Vogt's triad is a clinical finding associated with primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG). It includes • Glaukomflecken – Small, whitish, anterior subcapsular lens opacities due to ischemia of the lens epithelium • Posterior Synechiae – Adhesions between the iris and the lens due to prolonged pupillary block • Iris Atrophy – Thinning of the iris due to chronic ischemia Other options: A) Virchow's Triad associated with thrombosis (stasis, endothelial injury, and hypercoagulability) B) Hutchinson's Triad seen in congenital syphilis (Hutchinson teeth, interstitial keratitis, and deafness) D) Gaucher's Triad associated with Gaucher’s disease, which involves hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and pancytopenia

questions.text: On examination, a patient was found to have orbicularis oculi paresis, lagophthalmous, insensitive cornea. Which of the following might be responsible for this scenario?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The patient presents with • Orbicularis oculi paresis suggests facial nerve (CN VII) involvement, leading to incomplete eye closure (lagophthalmos) • Insensate cornea suggests trigeminal nerve (CN V) involvement, leading to loss of corneal sensation These findings are highly suggestive of leprosy (Hansen’s disease), which is caused by Mycobacterium leprae Other options: A) Acanthamoeba castellanii causes Acanthamoeba keratitis, associated with contact lens wear and severe corneal infection, but does not cause nerve palsies B) Onchocerca volvulus causes river blindness (onchocerciasis) with chronic keratitis, chorioretinitis, and blindness, but does not cause cranial nerve palsy D) Chlamydia A–C causes trachoma, leading to progressive conjunctival scarring and blindness, but does not involve facial or trigeminal nerve palsy

questions.text: Which of the following will cause punched out lesion in the retina?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Toxoplasmosis is the most common cause of "punched-out" chorioretinal scars. It is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, it leads to necrotizing retinochoroiditis, which heals with characteristic well-defined, punched-out chorioretinal scars with hyperpigmented edges. In congenital toxoplasmosis, lesions are typically bilateral and may be associated with intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus, and chorioretinitis Other Options: B) Congenital Rubella causes salt-and-pepper retinopathy, not punched-out lesions. Other findings include cataracts, microphthalmia, and sensorineural hearing loss C) Posterior Staphyloma seen in high myopia. Causes posterior scleral ectasia, not discrete chorioretinal punched-out lesions D) Choroidal Coloboma: A congenital malformation due to failure of choroidal fissure closure. It appears as large, pale, well-circumscribed defects in the retina and choroid but not punched-out lesions

questions.text: Which of the following has familial inheritance 1. Retinoblastoma 2. Retinitis pigmentosa 3. Myopia 4. Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A) Retinoblastoma: Autosomal dominant (RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13). Hereditary form is associated with bilateral or multifocal tumors B) Retinitis Pigmentosa: Autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked. Progressive degeneration of photoreceptors (rods first, then cones) C) Myopia: Polygenic inheritance with environmental factors. High myopia (> -6D) has a stronger genetic component D) Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG): Polygenic, with some Mendelian forms (MYOC, OPTN, and TBK1 gene mutations). First-degree relatives have a significantly higher risk of developing POAG

questions.text: A lady presented with one day history of sudden painless loss of vision in right eye. On examination, right eye has RAPD while other ocular examination was normal. What investigations will be helpful to confirm the diagnosis? 1. MRI brain and orbit with contrast 2. Estimation of Blood glucose, Liver and Renal function tests 3. Anti NMO and anti MOG antibody 4. Thyroid profile
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The presentation suggests optic neuritis (ON), ischemic optic neuropathy, or other optic nerve pathology. Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD) in the affected eye without any other ocular findings strongly indicates optic nerve involvement MRI Brain and Orbit with Contrast: Essential to assess optic nerve inflammation, demyelination, or compression. Helps diagnose multiple sclerosis (MS), neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD), or optic nerve tumors Estimation of Blood Glucose, Liver, and Adrenal Function Tests: Useful for metabolic disorders but not primary investigations for sudden painless vision loss Anti-NMO (Aquaporin-4) and Anti-MOG Antibodies helps differentiate NMO (NMO-IgG positive) from MOG (MOG-IgG positive). NMO-associated optic neuritis tends to be severe, recurrent, and bilateral Thyroid Profile: Thyroid dysfunction can be linked with some ocular diseases (e.g., thyroid eye disease), but it is not a primary cause of sudden painless vision loss with RAPD

questions.text: Identify the sign in the given pic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vossius ring appears as a circular or semi-circular brownish ring on the anterior lens capsule. It is composed of pigment deposits from the iris following blunt trauma to the eye. This occurs due to compression of the iris against the lens, leading to the transfer of pigmented epithelial cells. Other Options: Kayser-Fleischer Ring: A greenish-brown ring at the corneal periphery (Descemet’s membrane) due to copper deposition in Wilson's disease Fleischer Ring: A brownish or iron deposition ring seen in the cornea in Keratoconus, at the base of the cone Weiss Ring: A circular white/grayish floater seen in posterior vitreous detachment (PVD), due to detachment of the vitreous from the optic disc

questions.text: Identify the chart in the given pic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hess chart is used to assess ocular motility disorders and paralytic squints. It consists of a grid pattern where the patient uses red-green goggles to align dots, assessing ocular muscle function and deviations. It helps diagnose conditions like nerve palsies (3rd, 4th, 6th cranial nerves) and restrictive strabismus Other Options: Snellen Chart: Used to test visual acuity. It consists of letters of decreasing size viewed from a distance of 6 meters (20 feet) ETDRS Chart: Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) chart is used for standardized visual acuity testing, especially in research and clinical trials Pelli-Robson Chart: Used for contrast sensitivity testing. Letters of same size but decreasing contrast assess how well a person sees low-contrast objects

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) FOLLICLES SEEN IN INFECTIONS

questions.text: Where is the most likely lesion in the given visual field defect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce a bitemporal hemianopia due to compression or damage to the crossing nasal fibers from both eyes. This results in loss of vision in the temporal (outer) fields of both eyes, commonly caused by pituitary adenomas, craniopharyngiomas, or meningiomas Other options: Optic Tract (B): Causes contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of vision on the same side in both eyes). Example: Right optic tract lesion ? left homonymous hemianopia Optic Radiations (C): Lesions cause quadrantanopias due to division into upper and lower fibers. Meyer's loop (temporal lobe) ? superior quadrantanopia ("pie in the sky"), Parietal lobe ? inferior quadrantanopia ("pie on the floor") Occipital Lobe (D): Lesions cause homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (due to dual blood supply from PCA + MCA)

questions.text: Which step of cataract surgery is being done here?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Capsulorhexis refers to the continuous curvilinear tear made in the anterior lens capsule to allow access to the lens nucleus. This is a crucial step in phacoemulsification surgery as it helps in safe removal of the cataractous lens while preserving the integrity of the capsular bag for IOL implantation Other options: Lens Aspiration: This step comes later, where the remaining cortical material is aspirated after nucleus removal. It involves removal of soft lens material using suction, often after phacoemulsification Hydrodissection (C): Involves injecting fluid (BSS - Balanced Salt Solution) under the anterior capsule to separate the lens nucleus from the capsule. It occurs before phacoemulsification to facilitate lens rotation and safe removal Intraocular Lens (IOL) Implantation (D): This step is done after lens removal, where a foldable acrylic or PMMA lens is inserted into the capsular bag. It restores vision post cataract extraction

questions.text: A man with red eye presents to clinic. On examination, there were cells in the anterior chamber and keratic precipitates with Intraocular pressure was 36. Which drug is not to be given?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The patient presents with red eye, anterior chamber cells, keratic precipitates, and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP = 36 mmHg). This suggests uveitic glaucoma, which is secondary to anterior uveitis (inflammation of the anterior chamber) Prostaglandin analogs (e.g., latanoprost, bimatoprost, travoprost) should be avoided in uveitic glaucoma because • They increase inflammation by upregulating prostaglandin-mediated pathways • Can worsen blood-aqueous barrier disruption, leading to more anterior chamber inflammation • May cause cystoid macular edema (CME), especially in pseudophakic patients (those who have had cataract surgery) Other options: A) Mannitol used in acute IOP elevation to rapidly reduce pressure via osmotic diuresis. Draws fluid from the eye into the bloodstream, lowering IOP B) Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors (CAIs) (e.g., Acetazolamide, Dorzolamide) reduce aqueous humor production, lowering IOP. Oral Acetazolamide is preferred for rapid IOP reduction C) Beta-Blockers (e.g., Timolol) decreases aqueous humor production by inhibiting beta receptors in the ciliary body. Safe in uveitic glaucoma, but avoid in asthmatics or bradycardic patients

questions.text: A child with acute painful proptosis and small cells on histopathology which turned to be desmin positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The child presents with acute painful proptosis, and histopathology reveals small round blue cells that are desmin-positive Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common malignant orbital tumor in children • Small round blue cells • Desmin-positive (a marker of skeletal muscle differentiation) Other Options: B) Leukemia can cause orbital involvement, but it is usually painless proptosis. No desmin positivity; instead, CD45 (leukocyte common antigen) positive C) Ewing Sarcoma affects bones, particularly long bones and pelvis. Typically CD99 positive, not desmin positive. Orbital involvement is rare D) Chloroma (Granulocytic Sarcoma): Extramedullary manifestation of AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia). May present with greenish tumor masses, but it is myeloperoxidase (MPO) positive, not desmin positive

questions.text: Most classical route of spread of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most classical route of spread in retinoblastoma is via the optic nerve, which can lead to CNS involvement Other options: A) Direct spread: Retinoblastoma can invade nearby structures like the choroid and sclera, but optic nerve spread is more characteristic C) Lymphatic spread: The retina has no lymphatic drainage, so lymphatic spread is not a primary route D) Vascular spread: Hematogenous (vascular) spread can occur later in the disease, leading to metastasis in bone marrow, liver, and lungs, but optic nerve spread is more classical

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis seen in the nine gazes in the figure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The nine-gaze test is used to evaluate ocular motility disorders and cranial nerve palsies. In left 3rd nerve palsy, the following findings are typically seen • Ptosis on the affected side (due to levator palpebrae superioris paralysis) • Down and out eye position (due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique) • Pupil involvement (in cases of compressive lesions like aneurysms) • Inability to move the eye upward, downward, or medially (due to paralysis of superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique) Other options: A) Right 4th nerve palsy would cause hypertropia of the right eye, worsening in downgaze and contralateral gaze B) Left 4th nerve palsy would cause hypertropia of the left eye, worsening in downgaze and ipsilateral gaze D) Right 3rd nerve palsy would show similar features but affecting the right eye instead of the left

questions.text: Most common lacrimal gland tumour
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland, accounting for about 50-60% of all epithelial lacrimal gland tumors. It is a benign, slow-growing tumor but has the potential to undergo malignant transformation into carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma if not excised completely Other options: B) Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: Most common malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland but not the most common overall. Often presents as painless swelling in older adults C) Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma: Most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland. Known for perineural invasion, causing severe pain and poor prognosis D) Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma: Rare but aggressive malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland

questions.text: Which is not a component of SAFE strategy for trachoma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The SAFE strategy is a WHO-endorsed approach to eliminate trachoma, the leading infectious cause of blindness. It consists of S – Surgery for trichiasis A – Antibiotics (Azithromycin for active infection) F – Facial cleanliness to reduce transmission E – Environmental improvement (improving water supply & sanitation) "Evaluation of programme" is not a component of the SAFE strategy, though program evaluation is important in public health initiatives

questions.text: Where is the likely lesion here
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lesions in the occipital lobe cause contralateral homonymous hemianopia (same-sided visual field loss in both eyes) The answer is B (left occipital lobe), the patient most likely has right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing The lateral geniculate body (A) and optic chiasma (D) cause different types of defects (e.g., quadrant defects or bitemporal hemianopia)

choices.text: The pathology at level of trabecular meshwork is seen on gonioscopy
Family members have 1% risk of developing POAG
On dilating the pupil IOP always rises
Visual field defect can be there with normal cup disc ratio
First degree relatives of POAG patients having steroid responsiveness

questions.text: Which statements are true for association of Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) and (E) A) The pathology at the level of the trabecular meshwork is seen on gonioscopy: In POAG, the trabecular meshwork appears open and normal on gonioscopy. The actual pathology is microscopic obstruction of aqueous outflow due to extracellular matrix accumulation or endothelial dysfunction. B) Family members have 1% risk of developing POAG: First-degree relatives of POAG patients have a 10-fold increased risk compared to the general population. The actual risk is about 10-15%, not just 1%. C) On dilating the pupil, IOP always rises: In POAG, IOP may increase, remain stable, or even decrease after dilation. However, in angle-closure glaucoma, pupil dilation (e.g., with mydriatics) can precipitate an acute attack. D) Visual field defect can be there with normal cup-disc ratio: In early POAG, visual field defects (such as arcuate scotomas or nasal steps) can precede significant optic disc cupping. Structural changes (optic nerve head) and functional changes (visual fields) do not always correlate perfectly in the early stages. E) First-degree relatives of POAG patients have steroid responsiveness: First-degree relatives of POAG patients often have an increased steroid response, meaning they show a significant IOP rise when given corticosteroids. This suggests a genetic predisposition to steroid-induced glaucoma in these individuals

choices.text: Seen in superior and inferior Descement membrane
Seen in all patients with Hepatitis

questions.text: Which of the following are true regarding Kayser-Fleisher ring
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) KF rings are caused by copper deposition in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea. They typically start in the superior and inferior corneal periphery before becoming circumferential in advanced cases Other options: A) Pathognomonic of Wilson disease: While KF rings are highly suggestive of Wilson disease, they are not pathognomonic. They can also be seen in chronic cholestatic conditions (e.g., primary biliary cholangitis) and some cases of cryptogenic cirrhosis C) Seen in all patients with hepatitis: KF rings are not seen in all cases of hepatitis. They are associated with Wilson disease and some cholestatic liver diseases, but not with common viral hepatitis (Hepatitis B, C, etc.) D) Disappears with Deferoxamine: Deferoxamine is an iron chelator, not a copper chelator. KF rings improve with copper chelators like penicillamine, trientine, or zinc therapy as Wilson disease is treated

questions.text: Which drugs are required for assessment of a patient with fixed dilated pupil
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pilocarpine (0.1% and 1%) is used to differentiate between causes of pupil dilation Adie's tonic pupil: Supersensitive to dilute (0.1%) pilocarpine, causing constriction due to denervation hypersensitivity CN III palsy or pharmacologic dilation: No response to pilocarpine (even 1%), as the sphincter pupillae muscle is either nonfunctional or blocked by drugs like atropine. Other Options: A) 2.5% Phenylephrine – Used in Horner’s syndrome to assess postganglionic lesion (not relevant to fixed dilation) B) 4% Cocaine – Used in Horner’s syndrome diagnosis, detecting sympathetic denervation (not for fixed dilation) D) 1% Adrenaline – Not used in pupil assessment; mainly for systemic vasopressor effects

questions.text: Iritis seen in what all conditions among the following A. Systemic Lupus Erythematous B. Rheumatoid arthritis C. Ulcerative Colitis D. Bechets E. Psoriasis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Iritis can be seen in the following conditions A. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): Yes, iritis can occur in SLE, although it is less common compared to other ocular manifestations like scleritis. C. Ulcerative Colitis: Yes, iritis can be seen in some patients with Ulcerative Colitis, particularly those with associated inflammatory bowel disease. D. Behçet's Disease: Yes, iritis is strongly associated with Behçet's disease, as it is a vasculitis that commonly causes recurrent uveitis, including iritis. E. Psoriasis: Yes, iritis can occur in psoriatic arthritis, particularly if the patient is HLA-B27 positive, as psoriatic arthritis is linked to recurrent anterior uveitis (iritis). Iritis can't be seen in the following condition: B. Rheumatoid Arthritis: No, iritis is not typically seen in rheumatoid arthritis. RA is more commonly associated with scleritis and episcleritis rather than anterior uveitis like iritis. So, the conditions that can have iritis are SLE, Ulcerative Colitis, Behçet's disease, and Psoriasis.

questions.text: A patient having small pupil which remains same in dark as well. Which of the following condition could be the reason?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Horner syndrome results from sympathetic pathway disruption leading to • Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) • Miosis (small pupil that does not dilate in darkness) • Anhidrosis (loss of sweating on the affected side) • Apparent enophthalmos (sunken eye appearance) Cause: Lesion in the sympathetic pathway (e.g., Pancoast tumor, carotid dissection, brainstem stroke) Dilation lag is a key feature: the affected pupil dilates more slowly in darkness Other options: A) Blind eye: A blind eye can have a normal-sized pupil or a fixed, dilated pupil (if there is optic nerve damage). It does not necessarily cause persistent miosis in darkness C) Argyll Robertson Pupil seen in neurosyphilis, this pupil is small, irregular, and does not react to light but constricts with accommodation ("light-near dissociation"). However, it still dilates in darkness, unlike Horner syndrome D) Adie Pupil: Adie’s pupil is a tonic pupil, meaning it is large and sluggishly reactive to light and accommodation. It does not remain small in darkness but instead tends to be dilated due to parasympathetic dysfunction

questions.text: Patient came with left head tilt. On straightening of head, the doctor noticed right hypotropia which increased on dextroversion. Which is the most likely muscle paralysed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The key findings in the question: • Left head tilt • Right hypotropia (right eye lower than the left) • Hypotropia worsens on dextroversion (right gaze) Right superior rectus palsy comes with left head tilt Other options; A) Right superior oblique: The superior oblique depresses the eye in adduction, not in abduction B) Left superior oblique: Left superior oblique palsy would cause left hypertropia and worsen in left gaze, not right gaze D) Left inferior oblique: Left inferior oblique palsy would cause left hypotropia, not right hypotropia

choices.text: Apply eye ointment and then after 15 minutes eye drop
Apply eye ointment and then eye drop simultaneously
Apply eye drops and then 15 minutes after eye ointment
Any one can be put before other

questions.text: A patient was prescribed eye ointment and eye drop by doctor. What sequence should nurse follow out of these?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) When both eye drops and eye ointment are prescribed, the correct sequence ensures maximum absorption and effectiveness of the medication. Correct Sequence: 1. First, apply the eye drops – They are water-based and need to be absorbed quickly 2. Wait for at least 5-15 minutes – This allows proper absorption of the eye drops 3. Then, apply the eye ointment – Ointments are oil-based and create a barrier that could prevent eye drops from being absorbed properly if applied first A) Apply eye ointment and then after 15 minutes eye drops: The ointment forms a barrier that prevents proper absorption of eye drops B) Apply eye ointment and then eye drop simultaneously: The ointment will block the eye drop from reaching the cornea, reducing its effectiveness D) Any one can be put before the other: Sequence matters to ensure proper drug absorption and effectiveness

questions.text: A 40 year old patient who underwent LASIK for myopia previously is now undergoing cataract surgery. Formula used for lens power calculation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Patients who have undergone LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis) for myopia present a challenge in intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation during cataract surgery. This is because LASIK alters the corneal curvature, making traditional IOL power formulas less accurate A) SRK 1: Outdated and not suitable for post-refractive surgery patients B) SRK 2: Uses standard keratometry-based calculations, which are inaccurate in post-LASIK eyes D) Holladay: Holladay 1 and 2 are better than SRK formulas, but Haigis (or Haigis-L) is more preferred in post-LASIK eyes

choices.text: Stems cells are limited to limbus

questions.text: All of the following are features of corneal epithelium except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bowman’s membrane does not regenerate once damaged. It is an acellular layer made of collagen fibers and does not have regenerative capability. Damage to Bowman’s membrane leads to scar formation Other options: A) Lined by stratified squamous epithelium: The corneal epithelium is composed of non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, providing protection and a smooth refractive surface. C) Apical cells have microvilli: The superficial epithelial cells have microvilli, which help in retaining the tear film and enhancing corneal hydration and smoothness D) Stem cells are limited to the limbus: Limbal stem cells (located in the basal layer of the limbus) are responsible for regenerating the corneal epithelium. Damage to the limbus (e.g., chemical burns, Stevens-Johnson syndrome) leads to limbal stem cell deficiency, causing corneal opacity and vascularization

questions.text: What is the effect of increasing the numerical aperture of objective lens of a microscope?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The Numerical Aperture (NA) of an objective lens in a microscope is defined as NA = nsin(?) where: • n = refractive index of the medium between the lens and the specimen • ? = half-angle of the maximum cone of light entering the objective As NA increases, resolution improves, allowing finer details to be seen B) Higher magnification: NA influences resolution more than magnification. Magnification is determined by the optical design and does not directly depend on NA C) Higher degree of view: The field of view is determined by the eyepiece and objective combination, not just NA D) Higher working distance: Working distance (WD) decreases as NA increases because higher NA lenses require closer proximity to the specimen

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient is under treatment for epilepsy and he development permanent progressive concentric visual constriction. Which of the following drug causes this condition in most of the patients
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic drug that is known to cause permanent, progressive, concentric visual field constriction in a significant number of patients. Vigabatrin is an irreversible inhibitor of GABA transaminase, increasing GABA levels. The visual field defect is concentric, often sparing central vision Other options: A) Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is not known to cause visual field defects. It is generally well-tolerated and does not have significant retinal toxicity C) Phenobarbitone can cause sedation, cognitive impairment, and osteoporosis, but not visual field defects D) Ethosuximide used for absence seizures, but does not cause visual field constriction

choices.text: Diagnostic probing of Nasolacrimal duct obstruction

questions.text: Image of Elderly lady undergoing the procedure. Identify the procedure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Diagnostic probing of the nasolacrimal duct is a procedure performed in elderly patients (or sometimes in children) to evaluate nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO). The procedure involves inserting a lacrimal probe into the punctum and passing it through the nasolacrimal duct to assess patency. NLDO is common in elderly patients due to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, or age-related stenosis A) Anterior ethmoidal nerve block: Used for nasal surgeries (e.g., septoplasty, turbinate reduction). The nerve is blocked near the nasociliary nerve branch at the medial orbit—not related to nasolacrimal duct probing B) Vidian nerve block: Performed at the pterygopalatine fossa to treat chronic rhinitis or facial pain. Unrelated to lacrimal system C) Trephination refers to drilling a hole in the skull or sinuses (e.g., for sinus drainage). Not related to nasolacrimal duct procedures

questions.text: Which of these could be the possible in the given angiography picture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Angiography, specifically fluorescein angiography (FA) is used to evaluate retinal and choroidal circulation abnormalities. Findings in Macular Ischemia: Fluorescein angiography (FA) shows capillary dropout or enlargement of the foveal avascular zone (FAZ) in macular ischemia. This occurs due to damage to the retinal capillary network, often seen in diabetic retinopathy, retinal vein occlusion (RVO), or other ischemic retinopathies. There will be areas of non-perfusion in the macula with an enlarged or irregular FAZ Other options: A) Submacular hemorrhage: This would present as blocked fluorescence on FA due to blood accumulation beneath the retina, preventing dye transmission. Typically seen in wet age-related macular degeneration (AMD) or polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy (PCV) C) Macular oedema: FA in macular edema shows leakage from microaneurysms or capillaries, appearing as diffuse hyperfluorescence. Seen in diabetic macular edema (DME), retinal vein occlusion (RVO), or post-inflammatory conditions D) Premacular hemorrhage: This is a localized collection of blood in the sub-hyaloid space, commonly seen in Valsalva retinopathy or Terson syndrome. FA would show blocked fluorescence due to hemorrhage overlaying the macula

questions.text: Which nerves are responsible for eye movements
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) and (C) Eye movements are controlled by three cranial nerves 1. Oculomotor nerve (CN III) innervates most extraocular muscles Superior rectus (elevation) Inferior rectus (depression) Medial rectus (adduction) Inferior oblique (extorsion, elevation, abduction) Also controls pupil constriction (via parasympathetic fibers). 2. Abducens nerve (CN VI) innervates lateral rectus, which is responsible for abduction (moving the eye laterally) 3. Trochlear nerve innervates superior oblique, which causes intorsion, depression, and abduction

questions.text: Which is the layer marked in the picture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The inner plexiform layer (IPL) is a layer in the retina where bipolar cells synapse with ganglion cells and amacrine cells. It is located between the inner nuclear layer (INL) and the ganglion cell layer (GCL) Retinal Layer Structure (from outer to inner): 1. Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE) 2. Photoreceptor Layer (Rods & Cones) 3. Outer Nuclear Layer (ONL) (cell bodies of photoreceptors) 4. Outer Plexiform Layer (OPL) (synapse between photoreceptors & bipolar cells) 5. Inner Nuclear Layer (INL) (cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal & amacrine cells) 6. Inner Plexiform Layer (IPL) (synapse between bipolar, amacrine & ganglion cells) 7. Ganglion Cell Layer (GCL) 8. Nerve Fiber Layer (NFL) (axons of ganglion cells) 9. Internal Limiting Membrane (ILM)

questions.text: Which of the following is true? 1. Topiramate induces angle closure 2. Dorzolamide can decrease ocular blood flow 3. Central field defects seen in open angle glaucoma 4. Latanoprost is used with caution in patients of bronchial asthma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Topiramate can cause acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG) due to ciliary body swelling and forward displacement of the lens-iris diaphragm, leading to myopic shift and angle closure Dorzolamide (a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor) increases ocular blood flow rather than decreasing it While peripheral vision loss is more common in primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), advanced cases can show central field defects due to damage in the papillomacular bundle Unlike beta-blockers (e.g., timolol), which can exacerbate asthma, latanoprost (a prostaglandin analog) does not significantly affect bronchial function and is not contraindicated in asthma

questions.text: Enlargement of blind spot is seen in all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In optic nerve hypoplasia, the optic disc is smaller than normal, leading to a smaller, not enlarged, blind spot Other options: Papilledema: In papilledema (optic disc swelling due to raised intracranial pressure), the blind spot enlarges due to edema spreading into the peripapillary retina Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma: In POAG, glaucomatous cupping can lead to peripapillary retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) damage, contributing to blind spot enlargement Medullated (Myelinated) Nerve Fibres: Myelinated nerve fibers obscure parts of the retina, leading to enlargement of the blind spot

questions.text: ETDRS is used for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ETDRS (Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study) is a standardized grading system and chart used in diabetic retinopathy research and management Other Options: Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG): Not related to ETDRS. Visual field testing is preferred Corneal Topography: Measures corneal shape, commonly for keratoconus Corneal Endothelial Count: Done via specular microscopy, not ETDRS

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve supplying the muscle marked
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Right eye Trochlear changes direction of SUPERIOR OBLIQUE MUSCLE [marked] SO supplied by 4th nerve. Nucleus of trochlear nerve in MID BRAIN, AT THE LEVEL OF INFERIOR COLLICULUS. SUPPLIED BY CONTRALATERAL NUCLEUS [SO & SR] RIGHT TROCHLEAR LESION - LEFT SO PALSY

choices.text: Both A &R are true and R is correct explanation of A
Both A &R are true but R is not correct explanation of A
A is true R is false
A is false R is false

questions.text: Assertion (A): Topical steroids are contraindicated in viral corneal ulcer Reason(R): Topical steroids can increase intraocular pressure Select one of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Topical steroids can worsen viral corneal ulcers (e.g., herpes simplex keratitis) by suppressing immune responses, leading to uncontrolled viral replication, deeper stromal involvement, corneal thinning, and potential perforation Steroids can cause steroid-induced glaucoma by increasing intraocular pressure (IOP), but this is not the primary reason they are contraindicated in viral corneal ulcers The main reason topical steroids are contraindicated is due to worsening of viral replication and corneal damage, not just IOP elevation

questions.text: All of the following are used to control IOP except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid, and rather than lowering intraocular pressure (IOP), it can actually increase IOP in susceptible individuals by reducing aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork. Therefore, it is not used to control IOP and is the correct answer here.

choices.text: It is called as ArgylL Robertson pupil
The vision is normal in right eye
Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in both eyes

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B and C) SWINGING FLASH LIGHT EXAMINATION LEFT OPTIC NEURITIS

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Stereopsis test, which assesses binocular depth perception, the image likely depicts a test such as Titmus Fly Test These tests evaluate a person’s ability to perceive depth using both eyes together, which is crucial for binocular vision assessment Other options: A) Ocular deviation – (Incorrect, tests like cover-uncover test assess ocular deviation) C) Refractive errors – (Incorrect, tested with retinoscopy or autorefractors) D) Sensory anomalies – (Incorrect, but some stereopsis tests can indirectly suggest suppression or amblyopia)

questions.text: What is the ?rst step in the management of an 18 months old child whose both eyes are deviated medially:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A) Forced duction test – (Not the first step; used to differentiate between paralytic and restrictive strabismus, e.g., Duane syndrome) B) Examination under anesthesia – (Used in cases of suspected posterior segment pathology or when the child is uncooperative C) Refractive error testing – (Correct answer – First step in evaluation of esotropia, especially to rule out accommodative esotropia, which is corrected with glasses) D) Examination of fundus – (Important but not the immediate next step; done if there is suspicion of retinal pathology like retinoblastoma)

questions.text: After cataract surgery; Intraocular lens put uneventfully in a young patient what should be done then:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A) IOL replaced every 10 years – (Incorrect – Modern IOLs are designed to last a lifetime and do not require routine replacement.) B) Never replaced – (Correct – IOLs are permanent unless complications arise, such as dislocation, opacification, or refractive issues.) C) Replaced when secondary cataract develops – (Incorrect – Secondary cataract (posterior capsular opacification, PCO) is treated with YAG laser capsulotomy, not IOL replacement.) D) Replaced when presbyopia develops – (Incorrect – Presbyopia occurs due to loss of accommodation, which is already lost after cataract surgery. It is managed with multifocal or accommodating IOLs, not replacement.)

questions.text: Match the following ocular drugs with respect to their side effects:
questions.solution: Correct Answer C STEROIDS CAUSE POSTERIOR SUBCAPSULAR CATARACT CHLOROQUINE - BULLS EYE MACULOPATHY/RETINOPATHY.

questions.text: Fundus examination should be done in 45-year-old female with newly diagnosed diabetes mellitus with no visual symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, many patients have had undiagnosed hyperglycemia for years, so diabetic retinopathy (DR) may already be present. American Diabetes Association (ADA) Guidelines recommend fundus examination at diagnosis, then annually or as needed In Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, fundus examination starts 5 years after diagnosis since retinopathy takes time to develop A) After 2 years – Not the recommended guideline for type 2 diabetes B) After 5 years – This applies to Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, not Type 2 D) Doesn’t require fundus examination – All diabetics need periodic retinal screening

choices.text: Eyeball injury with a sharp weapon

questions.text: Mode of injury occurs in the given below image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A) Globe burst: Typically occurs due to high-impact blunt trauma, such as a punch, explosion, or sports injury, leading to rupture of the eyeball Other options: B) Eyeball injury with a sharp weapon: A penetrating injury would cause a more localized wound, not a globe burst C) Corrosive: Corrosive injuries usually cause chemical burns with conjunctival and corneal damage rather than a globe rupture D) Chemical: While chemical injuries can cause severe ocular damage, they do not directly result in a globe burst

choices.text: Remove the foreign body in OPD

questions.text: Which of the following should not be done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Remove the foreign body in OPD should not be done in OPD, especially if deeply embedded or penetrating • If the foreign body is deeply embedded, attempting to remove it in OPD can worsen the injury, cause further damage, or lead to infection • Instead, refer the patient for ophthalmic evaluation and possible surgical removal in a sterile setting Other options: B) Check refractive error: To assess visual acuity changes due to trauma C) Give antibiotics: To prevent secondary infection, especially in penetrating injuries D) Do primary survey: A systemic trauma survey is essential to rule out other injuries

questions.text: All are manifestation of dengue virus infection in eye except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dengue virus does not cause cataracts directly. Cataracts are more commonly associated with congenital infections (e.g., rubella), aging, or trauma B) Maculopathy: Dengue maculopathy presents with central scotomas, decreased vision, and foveolitis due to capillary leakage in the macula C) Vitreous hemorrhage: Thrombocytopenia in severe dengue can cause vitreous hemorrhage, leading to sudden vision loss D) Optic neuritis: Dengue-associated optic neuritis can present with painful vision loss, optic disc edema, and RAPD

questions.text: Which of the following is the nucleus for upwards gaze?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal (INC), located in the midbrain, is responsible for vertical gaze control, including upward gaze. It works with the rostral interstitial nucleus of the MLF (riMLF) to control vertical saccades Other options: A) PPRF (Paramedian Pontine Reticular Formation) controls horizontal gaze, not upward gaze. It coordinates signals for lateral rectus (CN VI) and medial rectus (CN III) for horizontal conjugate eye movements B) Nucleus Raphe Magnus: This nucleus is involved in pain modulation and serotonin release, not gaze control C) Cuneiform Nucleus: It is part of the reticular activating system (RAS) and is not directly involved in gaze control

questions.text: In diabetic 3rd nerve palsy all seen except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Diabetic 3rd nerve palsy is pupil-sparing because ischemic damage affects the core of the nerve (motor fibers) and spares the peripheral parasympathetic fibers, which control pupillary function. If pupil involvement is present, suspect compressive causes like an aneurysm (posterior communicating artery aneurysm) B) Ptosis – Levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) is supplied by CN III, leading to ptosis C) Outward downward rolling of pupil: The unopposed action of lateral rectus (CN VI) and superior oblique (CN IV) causes the eye to deviate down and out D) Normal pupillary reflex: Pupillary fibers are spared in ischemic diabetic neuropathy, so the light reflex remains normal

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the below histopathology picture of retina.+
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Drusen are yellowish deposits found between the RPE and Bruch’s membrane. It is seen in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), especially dry (non-exudative) AMD. Histologically, they contain lipids, proteins, and cellular debris B) Phagosome: Phagosomes are intracellular structures involved in cell digestion and are not a prominent feature in retinal pathology C) Basal Laminar Deposits are thickened RPE basement membranes with membranous debris. Seen in early AMD but different from drusen D) Basal Linear Deposits contain lipoproteinaceous material in Bruch’s membrane. Associated with late-stage AMD but distinct from drusen

questions.text: Stenopic slit is used for all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Corneal tattooing is done for cosmetic or therapeutic purposes, such as in leukoma. This procedure requires dye deposition into the cornea, which is unrelated to a stenopic slit Other options: A) Fincham’s Test helps differentiate true cataract vs. miotic pupil-related blur. A stenopic slit helps in this test by narrowing the light entry and reducing diffraction effects B) Determine the Axis of Cylinder: A stenopic slit is used to find the axis of astigmatism by allowing light to pass only through a narrow meridian, helping refine cylindrical correction D) Iridectomy: A stenopic slit mimics the effect of an iridectomy, helping in glaucoma assessment by allowing light entry through a specific portion of the pupil

questions.text: A patient is taking drugs for rheumatoid arthritis and has a history of cataract surgery 1 year back, the patient presented with sudden painless loss of vision, probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cystoid Macular Edema is a common cause of vision loss after cataract surgery (postoperative Irvine-Gass syndrome). Painless loss of vision occurs due to fluid accumulation in the macula. Flower petal appearance on FFA Risk factors: • Post-cataract surgery (even after 1 year) • Use of anti-inflammatory drugs for RA (e.g., NSAIDs, steroids) • Diabetic retinopathy, uveitis Other options: B) Macular Hole cause central vision loss, but they are not directly linked to cataract surgery or RA treatment. They typically present with metamorphopsia (distorted vision) C) Chloroquine Toxicity: Hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine toxicity can cause bull’s eye maculopathy, but this occurs gradually over years, not suddenly. Also, it causes bilateral vision loss, not a sudden decline post-cataract surgery D) Chronic Choroiditis typically presents with pain, inflammation, and vitritis, which are not mentioned in this case

questions.text: Which of the following is used as an adjuvant therapy for fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Atropine eye drops are used as an adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcers to provide cycloplegia (paralysis of the ciliary muscle) and pain relief by preventing painful ciliary spasm. Additionally, it helps reduce the risk of posterior synechiae formation (adhesion of the iris to the lens or cornea) Other options: B) Pilocarpine eye drops → Pilocarpine is a miotic (pupil-constricting agent) and is not used in corneal ulcers because it can increase inflammation and cause discomfort C) Dexamethasone → Corticosteroids are contraindicated in fungal corneal ulcers as they worsen the infection by suppressing the immune response D) Lidocaine → Local anesthetics like lidocaine are not recommended as they can delay corneal healing and may worsen the ulcer

questions.text: A 55-years-old man complaints of glare in eye while driving his car in the night, his best corrected vision 6/12.he had undergone cataract surgery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Glare while driving at night is a common symptom of posterior capsular opacification (PCO), which is the most frequent long-term complication after cataract surgery. Best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of 6/12 suggests a gradual decline in vision, which is typical for PCO. PCO occurs due to proliferation of residual lens epithelial cells on the posterior capsule, leading to opacification and symptoms similar to cataract recurrence Other options: A) Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) → ARMD primarily causes central vision loss and metamorphopsia (distorted vision) rather than glare C) Corneal degeneration → Conditions like Fuch’s endothelial dystrophy or keratopathy usually cause hazy vision, halos, and pain, rather than isolated glare D) Diabetic retinopathy (DR) → DR usually presents with gradual visual loss, floaters, or scotomas due to hemorrhages or macular edema, not just glare at night

questions.text: A 15-years-old boy presented with headache and blurring of vision. On examination there was limitation of movement in right eye and diplopia on looking towards left. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is caused by a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which disrupts communication between the abducens nucleus and the oculomotor nucleus Headache and blurring of vision – These can occur due to an associated demyelinating or inflammatory process Limitation of movement in the right eye – Suggests adduction weakness in the right eye Diplopia on looking towards the left – Suggests failure of the right eye to adduct while the left eye undergoes abduction nystagmus, which is classic for INO Other Options: A) TB meningitis → Can cause cranial nerve palsies but usually affects multiple nerves and presents with meningitic symptoms (fever, neck stiffness) C) Cranial neuritis → Would typically involve an isolated cranial nerve (e.g., optic neuritis affecting vision or isolated 6th nerve palsy). INO is due to an MLF lesion, not direct cranial nerve damage D) Demyelination → Demyelination (e.g., multiple sclerosis) can cause INO, but "Demyelination" is not a specific diagnosis like INO

questions.text: A 2yr old child brought by the parents with complaints of enlarged eyes and photophobia. Examination finding is as below. Most probable diagnosis is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Congenital glaucoma is the most probable diagnosis in a 2-year-old child with Enlarged eyes (Buphthalmos) – Due to increased intraocular pressure (IOP) causing stretching of the cornea and sclera Photophobia – Caused by corneal edema and light scattering Other possible findings – Epiphora (excessive tearing) and blepharospasm (involuntary eyelid closure) Other Options: B) Retinoblastoma → Presents with leukocoria (white reflex in the eye) and may cause strabismus, but not buphthalmos C) Congenital Endothelial Dystrophy → Can cause corneal clouding but not enlarged eyes. It is a non-progressive disorder D) Megalocornea → Large cornea is present, but there is no raised IOP, corneal edema, or photophobia. It is a non-progressive condition

questions.text: Identify the below image and it’s use.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Executive bifocals have a distinct line across the entire lens width, providing a clear separation between the distance and near segments. They are commonly used in pediatric pseudophakia (children who have undergone cataract surgery and do not have an intraocular lens implant). Since children lack accommodation after surgery, bifocals help them focus for both distance and near vision Other Options: A) Progressive Glasses for Presbyopia → Progressives have a smooth transition without a visible line. Not used in children B) Bifocal Glasses for Presbyopia → Similar to executive bifocals but typically have a smaller reading segment, making them less ideal for children D) Bifocals for Aphakia → Used in adult aphakia but executive bifocals are mainly used in pediatric pseudophakia

questions.text: Angle subtended by the topmost letter of snellen’s chart from 6 m distance
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The Snellen chart is designed such that the topmost letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes of arc (5?) per stroke and an overall angle of 50 minutes (50?) at a distance of 6 meters. Each component of the letter subtends 5 minutes, and the entire letter occupies 50 minutes of arc Other Options: A) 1 min ? This is the resolution limit for normal human vision, not the full letter size B) 5 min ? This corresponds to the stroke width of the letter, not the full letter height C) 30 min ? Incorrect, as the total angle is 50 minutes

questions.text: What is your most probable diagnosis on the below image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Superior oblique (SO) palsy affects the trochlear nerve (CN IV) and is the most common cause of vertical diplopia Key Features Suggesting SO Palsy: • Head tilt to the opposite side (Bielschowsky's sign) to compensate for extorsion • Hypertropia (affected eye appears higher) in primary gaze • Diplopia worsens on looking downward and towards the nose • Limited depression of the affected eye in adduction Other Options: A) Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO) → Characterized by impaired adduction and abduction nystagmus in the opposite eye, due to a medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) lesion B) Lateral Rectus Palsy → Causes horizontal diplopia with an inability to abduct the affected eye, due to a CN VI lesion D) Oculomotor Palsy → Leads to ptosis, a "down and out" eye, and pupil involvement (if compressive), due to a CN III lesion

questions.text: Struge Weber syndrome, most characteristic eye finding is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most characteristic eye finding in Sturge-Weber Syndrome (SWS) is glaucoma, which occurs due to increased episcleral venous pressure and abnormal anterior chamber angle development Other options: A) Keratitis → Not a characteristic feature of SWS C) Uveitis → No significant association with SWS D) Retinitis Pigmentosa → Found in inherited retinal dystrophies, not in SWS

questions.text: A patient presented with photophobia, watering and minimal hypopyon with feather like projections in corenel storma. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The key features in the case suggest fungal keratitis • Photophobia, watering – Common in corneal infections • Minimal hypopyon – Fungal infections often have a mild hypopyon • Feather-like projections in corneal stroma – A classic feature of fungal keratitis due to the filamentous growth of fungi Other Options: A) HSV Keratitis → HSV causes dendritic ulcers, not feathery infiltrates B) Acanthamoeba Keratitis → More commonly presents with ring-shaped stromal infiltrates and severe pain rather than feathery projections D) Pseudomonal Keratitis → Causes rapidly progressing ulcers with dense suppuration and significant hypopyon, rather than feathery infiltrates

questions.text: The given image shows before and after effect of phenylephrine administration on a lesion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Phenylephrine test is used to differentiate episcleritis from scleritis. Episcleritis involves superficial vessels, which blanch with 10% phenylephrine, while deeper scleral vessels in scleritis do not blanch. Nodular episcleritis presents as a localized, raised, red nodule on the sclera that becomes less red after phenylephrine administration Other Options: B) Tenon cyst → Typically appears as a translucent cystic lesion and is not affected by phenylephrine C) Pterygium → A triangular fibrovascular growth from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, not nodular and not affected by phenylephrine D) Phlycten → Seen in Phlyctenular Keratoconjunctivitis, presents as small, white inflammatory nodules, but they do not blanch with phenylephrine

choices.text: Fluorescein, then Rose Bengal, and then Lissamine green
Rose Bengal, then Lissamine green, and then Fluorescein
Lissamine green, then Rose Bengal and then Fluorescein
Rose Bengal, then fluorescein, and then Lissamine green

questions.text: For ocular examination, the order of staining for dry eyes is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fluorescein, then Rose Bengal, and then Lissamine green Fluorescein dye stains the denuded corneal epithelium green, which is seen in dry eyes. It also helps in testing Tear break up time. Rose Bengal gives a pink stain and stains necrotic tissue. Lissamine green dye stains tissues without affecting live tissues, hence is better than Rose Bengal. Practically, Fluorescein dye is done first.

questions.text: Which of the following are direct gonioscope? A. Koeppe B. Goldman C. Richardson D. Zeiss
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Direct Gonioscopes: These allow the examiner to view the angle directly by using a convex lens system. Examples include: • Koeppe lens • Richardson lens Indirect Gonioscopes: These use mirrors to reflect the image of the angle. Examples include: • Goldmann lens • Zeiss lens

questions.text: What structure is marked here by the red arrow?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The Canal of Petit (also called the retrolenticular space) is the space located between the posterior zonules and the anterior vitreous face. It is a part of the zonular apparatus, which helps maintain lens position. questions.text: A child came to OPD and was prescribed-2D sphere with -1D cylinder @180. What is the refractive error of that eye of the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This is compound myopic astigmatism because both meridians are myopic: one at −2.00 D (horizontal) and the other at −3.00 D (vertical). Since the vertical meridian (90°) is more myopic than the horizontal (180°), it corresponds to “with the rule” astigmatism — the eye is more curved vertically, which is typical in younger individuals. Option A — Compound hypermetropic astigmatism, with the rule Incorrect because hypermetropic astigmatism refers to both meridians being hyperopic (farsighted), whereas in this case both meridians are myopic (nearsighted). Option C — Simple myopic astigmatism, against the rule Incorrect because “simple” means only one meridian is myopic and the other is emmetropic (normal). In this case, both are myopic. Also, this is “with the rule,” not “against the rule,” since the vertical meridian has greater myopia. Option D — Mixed astigmatism, with the rule Incorrect because mixed astigmatism involves one meridian being myopic and the other being hypermetropic. Here, both meridians are myopic, so it doesn’t fit the mixed definition.

questions.text: A 21 year old boxer with spectacles needs to go for refractive surgery. Which of the following should be avoided?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A 21-year-old boxer is at high risk of ocular trauma, so the best refractive surgery should have minimal corneal weakening Radial Keratotomy (D) – Involves deep radial incisions that significantly weaken corneal integrity, making the eye highly susceptible to rupture with trauma. This makes RK the worst choice for a boxer Other options: LASIK (A) – Creates a corneal flap, which can be displaced by trauma, making it less ideal for boxers but still preferable to RK SMILE (B) – A flapless procedure, making it safer than LASIK for contact sports Photorefractive Keratectomy (PRK) (C) – No flap is created, making it a better option for athletes in high-contact sports

questions.text: What of the following will not be seen in severe Non Proliferative Diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Severe Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR) is characterized by extensive retinal ischemia but does not involve neovascularization. Neovascularization marks the transition to Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR) A) Venous Beading: Seen in severe NPDR due to vascular damage and ischemia B) Retinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA): These are pre-neovascular changes caused by ischemia, commonly found in severe NPDR C) Neovascularization at the Disc (NVD): Not seen in NPDR. It is a hallmark of PDR, where new vessels form due to VEGF-induced angiogenesis D) Retinal Hemorrhages: Present in NPDR, particularly dot, blot, and flame-shaped hemorrhages

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chuna is a strong alkali, causing severe chemical burns to the eye. If any remain, gentle mechanical removal can be done later

questions.text: What is the Investigation of choice for Best disease:

Calcifications seen on imaging (like ultrasound or CT scan) are highly suggestive of retinoblastoma. The history of prematurity might be misleading, but retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) does not typically present with intraocular calcifications Other options: Coats’ disease: Characterized by telangiectatic retinal vessels and exudation, but no calcifications Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP): Associated with prematurity but presents with retinal neovascularization and fibrosis, not intraocular calcifications Congenital cataract: Causes leukocoria but does not have calcifications

questions.text: A 80 yr old male presented with diminuition of vision since 2 yrs. The right eye was red and painful. On examination, the IOP was 50 mmHg in right eye and 16 mm Hg in left eye. The right eye had deep anterior chamber with some cells and flare. What could be the possibility?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Phacolytic glaucoma (Correct Answer): Phacolytic glaucoma is a secondary open-angle glaucoma caused by the leakage of high molecular weight lens proteins from a mature or hypermature cataract through an intact (but possibly permeable) lens capsule. These proteins are then phagocytosed by macrophages, which, along with the proteins themselves, obstruct the trabecular meshwork, leading to a significant increase in intraocular pressure (IOP). The patient's presentation fits perfectly: • 80-year-old male with 2 years of diminution of vision: This strongly suggests the presence of a long-standing and likely mature/hypermature cataract, which is the prerequisite for phacolytic glaucoma. • Red and painful right eye with IOP of 50 mmHg: This indicates acute, severe inflammation and significantly elevated pressure. • Deep anterior chamber: This is a hallmark feature of phacolytic glaucoma. Unlike angle-closure glaucomas, the mechanism here is an open angle clogged by material, not physical closure. • Cells and flare: This signifies an inflammatory reaction (uveitis), which is characteristic as the body responds to the leaked lens proteins and the presence of macrophages. All these findings are highly consistent with phacolytic glaucoma, where a mature cataract precipitates an acute inflammatory glaucoma. A. Malignant glaucoma (Incorrect Answer): Malignant glaucoma, also known as aqueous misdirection syndrome, is characterized by a misdirection of aqueous humor into the vitreous cavity, pushing the lens-iris diaphragm forward. The hallmark clinical sign of malignant glaucoma is a shallow or flat anterior chamber, often occurring after intraocular surgery (like glaucoma or cataract surgery), or sometimes spontaneously. The patient's presentation explicitly states a "deep anterior chamber," which directly contradicts the defining feature of malignant glaucoma. Therefore, this option is highly unlikely. C. Phacomorphic glaucoma (Incorrect Answer): Phacomorphic glaucoma is a type of secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by an intumescent (swollen) cataractous lens. The swollen lens pushes the iris forward, leading to pupillary block and mechanical closure of the anterior chamber angle. The defining characteristic of phacomorphic glaucoma is a shallow anterior chamber, which is caused by the forward displacement of the iris and lens. Since the patient in this scenario has a "deep anterior chamber," phacomorphic glaucoma is inconsistent with the findings. D. Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis (Incorrect Answer): Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI) is a chronic, low-grade, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis that is typically asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic, characterized by minimal inflammation ("quiet" eye). While FHI can be associated with secondary glaucoma (due to trabecular meshwork dysfunction) and cataract formation, the typical presentation is not an acutely "red and painful eye" with an IOP of 50 mmHg. The severe acute inflammation and extremely high pressure seen in this patient's right eye are far more consistent with an acute inflammatory event like phacolytic glaucoma rather than the chronic, insidious nature of FHI. Other classic signs of FHI like heterochromia or stellate keratic precipitates are also not mentioned.

choices.text: Early and specific feature is isoptre contraction and baring of blind spot
Visual field defects to be associated with glaucoma if associated with optic nerve head changes
In static perimetry, intensity of stimulus is kept constant while it is moved
Kinetic perimetry is best for monitoring field changes in glaucoma

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about glaucoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Visual field defects to be associated with glaucoma if associated with optic nerve head changes (Correct Answer) This statement is a fundamental principle in the diagnosis of glaucoma. Glaucoma is characterized by a progressive optic neuropathy, meaning damage to the optic nerve. This damage leads to specific and reproducible patterns of visual field loss. While visual field defects can arise from various conditions affecting the visual pathway (e.g., neurological disorders, retinal diseases), for a defect to be definitively attributed to glaucoma, it must correlate with characteristic structural changes observed in the optic nerve head (such as increased optic disc cupping, thinning of the neuroretinal rim, or retinal nerve fiber layer loss). This correlation between functional (visual field) and structural (optic nerve) damage is crucial for an accurate glaucoma diagnosis and distinguishes it from other conditions that might cause similar field loss patterns. Incorrect Options: A. Early and specific feature is isopter contraction and baring of blind spot (Incorrect Answer) While both isopter contraction (generalized constriction of the peripheral visual field) and baring of the blind spot (an extension of the normal blind spot) can be observed in glaucoma, they are not typically considered the earliest or most specific features. The earliest detectable visual field defects in glaucoma are more commonly localized defects within the central 30 degrees of vision, such as paracentral scotomas (areas of decreased sensitivity near the center of vision but not involving the fovea) or nasal steps (a sharp cutoff of vision along the horizontal meridian in the nasal field). Isopter contraction often indicates more advanced damage, and baring of the blind spot can sometimes be a normal variant or related to other conditions. C. In static perimetry, intensity of stimulus is kept constant while it is moved (Incorrect Answer) This statement incorrectly describes static perimetry. In static perimetry, the stimulus is presented at fixed locations in the visual field. For each of these fixed locations, the intensity of the stimulus is varied (usually starting from sub-threshold and increasing) until the patient perceives it. This process determines the retinal sensitivity threshold at that specific point. The description provided—keeping the intensity constant while moving the stimulus—actually describes kinetic perimetry (like Goldmann perimetry), where a stimulus of fixed intensity is moved from a non-seeing area into a seeing area to map out the boundaries of visual perception (isopters). D. Kinetic perimetry is best for monitoring field changes in glaucoma (Incorrect Answer) Kinetic perimetry, while useful for mapping the full extent of the peripheral visual field and for certain types of visual loss, is generally not considered the best method for monitoring subtle or progressive changes in glaucoma. Static automated perimetry (e.g., using a Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer) is preferred for glaucoma monitoring. Static perimetry offers several advantages, including greater sensitivity for detecting early, subtle defects (like paracentral scotomas which are common in glaucoma), the ability to provide quantitative threshold values, and the use of sophisticated statistical analysis software (e.g., Guided Progression Analysis) to track progression over time. These features make static perimetry more reliable for detecting the often subtle and gradual visual field changes characteristic of glaucoma progression.
